i strongly oppose cms' proposal to reduce payment for physical therapy providers by 9% in 2021. if this payment reduction is adopted, access to vital outpatient physical therapist services will be at grave risk. some physical therapy providers will need to close their doors while others may choose not to continue to treat medicare beneficiaries and/or refuse to accept new medicare patients. this will make it more difficult for medicare beneficiaries to access the services they need, leading to delays in receiving care and, as a result, a slower road to recovery. this also will lead to negative health outcomes and greater overall cost to the system. the federal government, as well as patients and taxpayers, are better served in the long run by ensuring that the medicare program promotes efficient treatment of beneficiaries, which cannot happen unless there are enough providers to do so. as the u.s. population ages, access to these services is vital to our quality of life.

cms has failed to consider the economic and social impacts that this significant payment reduction will have on beneficiary access to physical therapy. this massive adjustment to the fee schedule will cause disruptive reductions to revenue that, in turn, will severely jeopardize patient access to care. these concerns are magnified by the significant economic hit physical therapy providers have taken in the past few months as a result of the covid-19 pandemic. by hindering the ability of medicare beneficiaries to receive care, cms is putting the health of medicare beneficiaries at risk while also causing detrimental harm to the integrity of the medicare program. i have serious concerns that the inability of medicare beneficiaries to receive care in a timely manner will have a compounding negative effect on their health and quality of life.

further, cms' actions are not singular, a fact of which the agency is well aware. other payers tie their fee schedules directly or indirectly to the medicare physician fee schedule. this one payment policy will cause access to be limited not only for medicare beneficiaries, but also veterans, tricare enrollees, and commercially insured and self-pay patients.

as stated above, i oppose the estimated 9% payment reduction to physical therapy providers beginning in 2021. i strongly recommend that cms halt implementation of any cuts to physical therapist services.

thank you for your consideration.
21773:
as a health care professional who provides rehabilitation services to medicare beneficiaries, i am very concerned about proposals to be implemented under the 2021 physician fee schedule. on behalf of myself and the many medicare patients i hope to continue to serve, i respectively request reconsideration of the catastrophic payment reductions proposed for rehabilitation services. i also recommend that cms permanently allow telehealth services to be provided by rehabilitation professionals.

rehabilitation payment reductions

during most of 2020, i have done everything in my power to provide medically necessary care to medicare patients and prevent the spread of covid-19. along with my peers, i have met compliance to professional standards of care and medicare coverage policies while risking daily exposure to a deadly virus. not only have i spent a portion of every workday donning and doffing personal protective equipment, i have had to restructure treatment to accommodate patients kept in isolation and to utilize technology never before permitted by my profession in many medicare settings. despite my willingness to do all that is asked of me to assure patients are provided with the treatment they need, i am dismayed to learn that cms is proposing to devalue that care by an average of 9% per service. i am concerned that this severe reduction will result in reduced access to care at a time when patients are most in needespecially the patients i serve in nursing facilities. as a rehabilitation clinician, i am the face of health care every medicare beneficiary in need of rehabilitation therapy sees. i am entrusted with the care of medically fragile loved ones who must be carefully and competently treated. as a caring professional, i am very concerned that the impending payment reductions could result in medicare beneficiaries being severely challenged to access the rehab care they need. these reductions could also yield an economically devastating blow to all rehabilitation professions.

i love the work i do and i know the skills i have are needed for the medically complex population in our nation's nursing facilities. we are already facing cuts to rehab and we have additional cuts on the horizon. i am concerned that these additional reductions in payments will disallow and gradually dissolve a sufficient workforce to service those who need rehabilitation services. i respectfully request that you reconsider the reductions to rehabilitation therapy that cms is putting into place for 2021.

telehealth

with respect to telehealth services, it was gratifying to learn that cms expanded permission for rehabilitation therapists to use telehealth during the public health emergency. for patients unable to participate in traditional hands-on treatment, it was welcomed relief to have the opportunity to utilize telehealth in a way non-medicare treatment has been proven to be effective. as the pandemic continues and exposure risks remain, it would be best for both the patient and rehabilitation provider to have telehealth as a viable option when developing a plan of care. also and despite the duration of the public health emergency, i ask cms to allow me the professional discretion to use telehealth when it would be in the patient's best interest. out of the necessity to restructure treatment from traditional medicare models during the pandemic, we have learned telehealth is often a viable option with positive outcomes. outside the medicare community, we know that telehealth is a preferred method of treatment under certain circumstances. as a fully credentialed and professional health care provider, i ask cms to allow me to include telehealth among the acceptable treatment options.

thank you very much for the opportunity to submit these comments regarding the proposed physician fee schedule for 2021. hopefully, these comments provide evidence of my concerns and my desire to provide efficient and effective rehabilitation therapy.
13936:
i appreciate the opportunity to provide comments to the centers for medicare & medicaid services in response to the 2021 physician fee schedule proposed rule.



i work at fox rehabilitation, a large private practice of physical, occupational, and speech therapists who specialize in providing housecalls to medicare beneficiaries under part b. our typical patient is in their mid-80s with 5 comorbidities. in 2019, we provided over 1.5 million housecalls to medicare beneficiaries to improve their functional status and keep them healthy and safe at home. like cms independence at home initiative, this level of service from a pt, ot, or slp provides a unique opportunity to reduce costs to medicare while also improving overall health outcomes and functional independence.



i strongly oppose cms significant payment reductions for outpatient therapy services. a 9% cut to outpatient therapy will drastically impact my practices ability to care for patients. we will not be the only practice who will have to make tough decisions in response. we will have to consider pay cuts, increased productivity expectations, and reducing all the resources provided to clinicians to ensure the quality of their care. this will no doubt make it more difficult for beneficiaries to access the quality care they have become accustomed to receiving from our practice. patients who are unable to access care will have to turn to lesser trained professionals who cannot appropriately assess and dose exercise for them or go without care all together. lack of care will cause their quality of life to decline, leading to increased hospitalizations, and many moving to more intense levels of care that will fuel increased costs to the medicare system.



in addition, this cut will be compounded by the impact of the current public health emergency. as providers in the home, we have seen many patients who would not go to outpatient clinics due to fear of covid-19 but would allow us into their home to receive care. we have worked through the same difficulties with ppe that other front-line responders have had while serving this most vulnerable population. reducing payment for our services during this public health emergency is an irresponsible decision and puts medicare beneficiaries at risk of not being able to access care in the safest way possible.



separately, i would encourage cms to add cpt codes typically billed by physical, occupational, and speech therapists to the list of covered telehealth services. as a practice we have found telehealth to be a vital tool for appropriate patients during this public health emergency and have worked hard to ensure it is used responsibly. adding these services now will ensure an easy transition when physical, occupational, and speech therapists are included as telehealth providers in the future. i also strongly support cms proposal to permanently allow therapists to furnish and bill e-visits, remote assessment of recorded video and/or images submitted by an established patient, and brief communication technology-based service, e.g., virtual check-in.



i would also encourage cms to allow therapists the ability to utilize cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458. remote monitoring of patients would allow us a greater understanding of performance of and response to physical activity as well as information to better gauge a patients home exercise program and determine the need for advancing or revising programs. cms must revise its interpretation to recognize that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 may be billed by all qualified healthcare professionals who meet all statutory requirements, and that the billing of these codes is not limited solely to health care professionals who can bill medicare for e/m services.



finally, i strongly support cms proposal to allow assistants to furnish maintenance therapy under part b.

dear administrator verma:
on behalf of the western university of health sciences dpt program pomona, i appreciate the opportunity to provide comments to cms in response to the 2021 physician fee schedule proposed rule.
halt implementation of 9% cut to physical therapy providers
i strongly oppose cmsâ significant payment reductions for physical therapy services. if the 9% cut is implemented, physical therapy providers, many of whom are small business owners, will become insolvent and therefore unavailable to treat medicare beneficiaries, including medicare advantage enrollees. the result of this proposal will be massive unemployment; the shuttering of many small business (including in rural communities); delivery of unskilled care; significant declines in beneficiariesâ quality of life; and increased morbidity and mortality â all of which lead to greater costs and burdens on the already taxed health care system. the ripple effect that this decision will have across the provider community is monumental.
the unanticipated public health emergency declared in 2020 and the subsequent sharp decline in patient visits combined with incredible economic challenges have added significantly to concerns of whether or not providers will be able to afford to keep running their clinics, rehabilitation agencies, home health agencies, nursing homes, and hospital outpatient departments. furthermore, it is clear that the recovery and restoration to full patient utilization will be drawn out. looking longer term, the inevitable issues of access to care, rising debt, and shrinking reimbursement will provide the perfect storm for discouraging the next generation of individuals from choosing to enter the physical therapy profession at all. shortages of physical therapists will only become more problematic as baby boomers (both patients and retiring providers) are of medicare age while more individuals are seeking access to effective nonpharmacological services.
while i appreciate that cms has proposed to increase the work relative value units of the physical therapy evaluation and re-evaluation codes, it is not enough to offset the damage that will be caused by this across-the-board cut due to the application of the budget neutrality adjustment to the conversion factor. the 9% cut, if finalized, will cause a serious financial strain on outpatient physical therapy providers. these cuts will only create more harm to the health care system that is working tirelessly to fight the pandemic.
therefore, i strongly recommend that cms immediately halt implementation of the 9% reduction to physical therapy services.
include physical therapy codes in list of covered telehealth services
i strongly recommend that cms include in the list of covered telehealth services the following cpt codes: 97161, 97162, 97163, 97164, 97165, 97166, 97167, 97168, 97110, 97112, 97116, 97535, 97750, 97755, 97760, 97761, and 97530 and 97763. the expansion of telehealth payment and practice policies to allow physical therapists in private practice and facility-based physical therapy providers during this public health emergency has demonstrated that many needs can be effectively met via the use of technology and that patients can have improved access to skilled care by leveraging these resources. adding these cpt codes to the list of covered telehealth services will better ensure a seamless transition when additional practitioners, such as physical therapists, become eligible to furnish and bill for telehealth services under medicare.
moreover, adding these cpt codes, even on a temporary basis, will allow therapists who work âincident toâ physicians to continue to furnish telehealth services when appropriate, therefore ensuring continued access and improving beneficiariesâ satisfaction after the phe ends.
finalize the proposal to permanently allow physical therapists to furnish and bill communication technology-based services
i strongly support cmsâ proposal to permanently allow physical therapists to furnish and bill e-visits, remote assessment of recorded video and/or images submitted by an established patient, and brief communication technology-based service, e.g., virtual check-in. however, i recommend that cms clarify in final rulemaking that facility-based therapy providers, who have been identified as eligible to furnish and bill these communication technology-based services during the phe, also are recognized as eligible to furnish and bill these codes on a permanent basis.
recognize physical therapists as eligible to furnish and bill remote physiologic monitoring services
i respectfully disagree with cmsâ interpretation that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 can only be furnished and billed by physicians or practitioners who are eligible to bill medicare for e/m services. physical therapists are recognized by the american medical association as qualified health care professionals and the cpt codes at issue are not restricted to use solely by physicians and others who may bill e/m services.
physical therapists use remote monitoring technology in treatment to shorten healing times, reduce risk for adverse events, promote patient self-efficacy, improve comfort and quality of life, and increase the overall quality and options of care available. physical therapists use accelerometers and devices that collect physiologic functions both in real time (in person and remotely) and recorded. they commonly collect data that includes change in upper or lower extremity position, or displacement, that occurs over a given time period, heart rate, blood pressure, pulse, and respiration. this provides a greater understanding of performance of and response to physical activity as well as information to better gauge their home exercise program and determine the need for advancing or revising programs. physical therapists also use accelerometry to collect data that indicates when a patient may be experiencing balance and or postural changes that may be indications of increased falls risk.
physical therapists are recognized as qhps by ama; the definition of qhp supports the interpretation that physical therapists are qhps; and the remote physiologic monitoring codes are not e/m services. therefore, cms must revise its interpretation in final rulemaking to recognize that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 may be billed by qhps, such as physical therapists, who meet all statutory requirements, and that the billing of these codes is not limited solely to health care professionals who can bill medicare for e/m services.
finalize the proposal to allow physical therapist assistants to furnish maintenance therapy across outpatient settings
i strongly support cmsâ proposal to allow physical therapist assistants to furnish maintenance therapy under part b. i urge the agency to finalize this proposal in final rulemaking.
conclusion
thank you for the opportunity to comment on the cy 2021 pfs proposed rule. i stand ready to work with cms to identify a solution that will safeguard the financial health of the medicare program while ensuring that beneficiaries have adequate access to high-quality physical therapy services in the future.
thank you for your consideration.
taylor warinner-calixto
student physical therapist

dear administrator verma:
i am an occupational therapist residing in pa. i work in the health and wellness arena. i appreciate the opportunity to comment on this proposed rule published at 85 federal register 50074 on august 17, 2020.
proposed e/m policy and related cuts for 2021
i understand that due to budget neutrality, when increases are made to some codes, reductions must be made to others. however, the proposed 9% decrease to therapy services would be highly detrimental to the profession of occupational therapy, especially coupled with the other reimbursement cuts that therapy services have taken in recent years, and will continue to take with the ota payment reduction, which is effective in 2022.
the cumulative nature of mppr, sequestration, and the ota payment modifier is already substantial and hard felt, particularly by practitioners in rural and underserved areas. as a result, occupational therapy private practices and outpatient clinics may need to reduce operations or close their small businesses altogether. moreover, the aging population is in greater need of occupational therapy practitioners than ever before. access to these services is essential for medicare beneficiaries who wish to age in place, particularly for the growing demographic with chronic conditions, but a single reimbursement cut of this magnitude may make practicing unsustainable for the profession.
for example, i provide community based services to a wide age range of ages. i am on a fixed income and a 9% payment cut will definitely impact my ability to provide effective therapy at the same level of service i provide now.
while the work relative value unit (rvu) increases to therapy evaluation and re-evaluation codes is appreciated, the increased value does not adequately off set the cuts to therapy intervention services. therapy services all require management of the whole patient, including medically complex patients with multiple medical conditions. therapy progress reports, which are required every 10 visits, involve the same assessment skills as a re-evaluation. the medicare benefit policy manual chapter 15, section 220.3.d states that âprogress reports shall include assessment of improvement, plans for continuing treatment, additional evaluation results, and treatment goals.â all of these elements make progress reports analogous to evaluation and management services. because progress reports are not billable by their own cptâ® code, they are performed and included on days that therapy interventions are performed. therefore, we respectfully request that the mostly commonly billed therapy interventions, 97530 and 97110, be granted rvu increases to reflect the assessment- and management-focused components required to complete the progress report, since these components are analogous in many respects to the ot evaluation and re-evaluation codes.
other services provided by occupational therapists that have a clearly established assessment and management component and therefore should be considered for additional reimbursement through rvu increases in the cy 2021 mpfs final rule include:
97542	wheelchair management (e.g., assessment, fitting, training), each 15 minutes
97755	assistive technology assessment (e.g., to restore, augment, or compensate for existing function, optimize functional tasks, and/or maximize environmental accessibility), direct one-on-one contact, with written report, each 15 minutes
97760	orthotic(s) management and training (including assessment and fitting when not otherwise reported), upper extremity(ies), lower extremity(ies), and/or trunk, initial orthotic(s) encounter, each 15 minutes
97761	prosthetic(s) training, upper and/or lower extremity(ies), initial prosthetic(s) encounter, each 15 minutes
97763	orthotic(s)/prosthetic(s) management and/or training, upper extremity(ies), lower extremity(ies), and/or trunk, subsequent orthotic(s)/prosthetic(s) encounter, each 15 minutes
i urge cms to reconsider the distribution of payment reductions for budget neutrality and, at a minimum, grant additional rvu reimbursement consideration for the following therapy cpt codes to help offset the budget neutrality cuts: 97530, 97110, 97542, 97755, 97760, 97761, and 97763.
telehealth
i have been surprised at the effectiveness of telehealth services. i am able to treat each client with individualized and personalized care. clients are able to implement their treatment well, under my direction. the clientâs attention is focused and sustained. treatment success has been quick. family members are easily brought into the treatment session as needed.
telehealth expands the reach of therapy services particularly for rural and underserved populations. therapy provided telehealth broadens the ability for therapists to reach a wider market in a cost effective and time efficient manner. providing preventative care keeps patients out of the hospitals and facilitates health while reducing overall medical costs.
i fully support the continuation of telehealth services being available for our occupational therapy profession.
expand telehealth flexibilities permanently to therapy practitioners
while i appreciate the consideration cms gave to occupational therapy, physical therapy, and speech-language pathology practitioners to perform telehealth for the duration of the covid-19 public health emergency (phe), i have concerns about my patientsâ ongoing therapy and rehabilitation issues after the phe ends and the waivers are revoked or expire. i ask that cms consider longer waiver coverage while the agency considers lifting the phe. until there is a vaccine, covid-19 will continue to be present in our communities and health care facilities. further, data currently indicates that the united states is likely to experience a second wave in the winter that could be followed by a third wave before a vaccine is developed. it is imperative for cms to maintain all health regulatory protections for as long as possible for the safety of the vulnerable beneficiary population and to assure efficient access to timely health care services. one of those critical protections for outpatient practices and institutional settings is the extension of telehealth. i urge cms to extend the therapy services telehealth waiver flexibility beyond the phe so that beneficiaries are not left suddenly without viable and safe rehabilitation treatment options. the additional time will also allow congress to assess the data from the phe and make decisions on the permanence of telehealth for therapy professionals. in addition, a longer term extension will assure patients who have successfully been accessing ot, pt, and/or slp via telehealth during the duration of the phe that they will not suddenly be discontinued from an effective and safe modality of treatment. such a sudden discontinuance of telehealth could result in medicare patients experiencing further functional decline, potentially leading to hospitalizations or re-hospitalizations.
add therapy services to the telehealth services list

adding the above listed cpt codes to the category iii list, in combination with extending waiver flexibilities to allow therapists to perform telehealth beyond the phe, is the best solution to ensure the best possible outcomes for medicare beneficiaries.

therapy assistants performing maintenance therapy
i thank cms for proposing allowing occupational therapy assistants to perform maintenance therapy under the medicare physician fee schedule (mpfs). this change aligns the mpfs policy with cmsâ policy for all other settings and assures consistency and continuity of care across medicare programs for patients receiving therapy services.

i am writing in response to the request for comments on the centers for medicare & medicaid services recently proposed 2021 revisions to payment policies under the physician fee schedule and other revisions to medicare part b (cms-1734-p).

as a health care professional who provides rehabilitation services to medicare beneficiaries, i am very concerned about proposals to be implemented under the 2021 physician fee schedule. on behalf of myself and the many medicare patients i hope to continue to serve, i respectively request reconsideration of the catastrophic payment reductions proposed for rehabilitation services. i also recommend that cms permanently allow telehealth services to be provided by rehabilitation professionals.

rehabilitation payment reductions

during most of 2020, i have done everything in my power to provide medically necessary care to medicare patients and prevent the spread of covid-19. along with my peers, i have met compliance to professional standards of care and medicare coverage policies while risking daily exposure to a deadly virus. not only have i spent a portion of every workday donning and doffing personal protective equipment, i have had to restructure treatment to accommodate patients kept in isolation and to utilize technology never before permitted by my profession in many medicare settings. despite my willingness to do all that is asked of me to assure patients are provided with the treatment they need, i am dismayed to learn that cms is proposing to devalue that care by an average of 9% per service. i am concerned that this severe reduction will result in reduced access to care at a time when patients are most in needespecially the patients i serve in nursing facilities. as a rehabilitation clinician, i am the face of health care every medicare beneficiary in need of rehabilitation therapy sees. i am entrusted with the care of medically fragile loved ones who must be carefully and competently treated. as a caring professional, i am very concerned that the impending payment reductions could result in medicare beneficiaries being severely challenged to access the rehab care they need. these reductions could also yield an economically devastating blow to all rehabilitation professions.

i love the work i do and i know the skills i have are needed for the medically complex population in our nation's nursing facilities. we are already facing cuts to rehab and we have additional cuts on the horizon. i am concerned that these additional reductions in payments will disallow and gradually dissolve a sufficient workforce to service those who need rehabilitation services. i respectfully request that you reconsider the reductions to rehabilitation therapy that cms is putting into place for 2021.

telehealth

with respect to telehealth services, it was gratifying to learn that cms expanded permission for rehabilitation therapists to use telehealth during the public health emergency. for patients unable to participate in traditional hands-on treatment, it was welcomed relief to have the opportunity to utilize telehealth in a way non-medicare treatment has been proven to be effective. as the pandemic continues and exposure risks remain, it would be best for both the patient and rehabilitation provider to have telehealth as a viable option when developing a plan of care. also and despite the duration of the public health emergency, i ask cms to allow me the professional discretion to use telehealth when it would be in the patient's best interest. out of the necessity to restructure treatment from traditional medicare models during the pandemic, we have learned telehealth is often a viable option with positive outcomes. outside the medicare community, we know that telehealth is a preferred method of treatment under certain circumstances. as a fully credentialed and professional health care provider, i ask cms to allow me to include telehealth among the acceptable treatment options.

thank you very much for the opportunity to submit these comments regarding the proposed physician fee schedule for 2021. hopefully, these comments provide evidence of my concerns and my desire to provide efficient and effective rehabilitation therapy.

my work is truly imperative to the geriatric community i serve in addition to cms to prevent falls, which could lead to costly fracture repairs. by avoiding cuts, i can continue to provide a service that not only improves the mobility of our aging population, but my work decreases risk of hospitalizations and falls, both of which are very costly to cms.
i appreciate the opportunity to provide comments to the centers for medicare & medicaid services in response to the 2021 physician fee schedule proposed rule.

first, i strongly oppose cms significant payment reductions for physical therapy services. if the 9% cut is implemented, physical therapy providers, many of whom are small business owners, will become insolvent and therefore unavailable to treat medicare beneficiaries, including medicare advantage enrollees. the result of this proposal will be massive unemployment; the shuttering of many small business (including in rural communities); delivery of unskilled care; significant declines in beneficiaries quality of life; and increased morbidity and mortality  all of which lead to greater costs and burdens on the already taxed health care system. the ripple effect that this decision will have across the provider community is monumental. cms must immediately halt implementation of the 9% reduction to physical therapy services.

second, i strongly recommend that cms include in the list of covered telehealth services the following cpt codes: 97161, 97162, 97163, 97164, 97165, 97166, 97167, 97168, 97110, 97112, 97116, 97535, 97750, 97755, 97760, 97761, and 97530 and 97763. the expansion of telehealth payment and practice policies to allow physical therapists in private practice and facility-based physical therapy providers during this public health emergency has demonstrated that many needs can be effectively met via the use of technology and that patients can have improved access to skilled care by leveraging these resources. adding these cpt codes to the list of covered telehealth services will better ensure a seamless transition when additional practitioners, such as physical therapists, become eligible to furnish and bill for telehealth services under medicare. moreover, adding these cpt codes, even on a temporary basis, will allow therapists who work incident to physicians to continue to furnish telehealth services when appropriate, therefore ensuring continued access and improving beneficiaries satisfaction after the phe ends.
third, i strongly support cms proposal to permanently allow physical therapists to furnish and bill e-visits, remote assessment of recorded video and/or images submitted by an established patient, and brief communication technology-based service, e.g., virtual check-in. however, i recommend that cms clarify in final rulemaking that facility-based therapy providers, who have been identified as eligible to furnish and bill these communication technology-based services during the phe, also are recognized as eligible to furnish and bill these codes on a permanent basis.
fourth, i respectfully disagree with cms interpretation that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 can only be furnished and billed by physicians or practitioners who are eligible to bill medicare for e/m services. physical therapists are recognized by the american medical association as qualified health care professionals and the cpt codes at issue are not restricted to use solely by physicians and others who may bill e/m services. physical therapists use remote monitoring technology in treatment to shorten healing times, reduce risk for adverse events, promote patient self-efficacy, improve comfort and quality of life, and increase the overall quality and options of care available. physical therapists use accelerometers and devices that collect physiologic functions both in real time (in person and remotely) and recorded. they commonly collect data that includes change in upper or lower extremity position, or displacement, that occurs over a given time period, heart rate, blood pressure, pulse, and respiration. this provides a greater understanding of performance of and response to physical activity as well as information to better gauge their home exercise program and determine the need for advancing or revising programs. physical therapists also use accelerometry to collect data that indicates when a patient may be experiencing balance and or postural changes that may be indications of increased falls risk.

physical therapists are recognized as qhps by ama; the definition of qhp supports the interpretation that physical therapists are qhps; and the remote physiologic monitoring codes are not e/m services. therefore, cms must revise its interpretation in final rulemaking to recognize that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 may be billed by qhps, such as physical therapists, who meet all statutory requirements, and that the billing of these codes is not limited solely to health care professionals who can bill medicare for e/m services.

finally, i strongly support cms proposal to allow physical therapist assistants to furnish maintenance therapy under part b.

i work at fox rehabilitation, a large private practice of physical, occupational, and speech therapists who specialize in providing housecalls to medicare beneficiaries under part b. our typical patient is in their mid-80s with 5 comorbidities. in 2019, we provided over 1.5 million housecalls to medicare beneficiaries to improve their functional status and keep them healthy and safe at home. like cms independence at home initiative, this level of service from a pt, ot, or slp provides a unique opportunity to reduce costs to medicare while also improving overall health outcomes and functional independence.

to whom it may concern:

i am a licensed acupuncturist in ohio. i am submitting this response to proposed changes in the 2021 cms fee schedule for cpt codes 97810-97814.

i am concerned that this fee reduction will decrease patients ability to access care.

i disagree that cpt codes 97810-97814 are clinically similar with dry needling codes. the expertise, skill and intensity required for codes 97810- 97814 is distinct from codes 20560-20561 and they should not be cross walked. furthermore, the procedures themselves are nowhere similar. the precision and decision making involved in acupuncture is far beyond that of dry needling. this is why the ama established two distinct cpt codes for acupuncture and dry needling/trigger point acupuncture procedures. one significant difference is that the acupuncture codes include pre- and post-service work up (as per the ama cpt instructions) whereas the dry needling/trigger point acupuncture codes do not. another difference is the intensity of diagnostics. acupuncture point selection typically requires at least 5 to 10 points placed bilaterally in multiple body regions, and is considerably more involved than straightforward dry needling/trigger point acupuncture. these differences distinguish the skill and intensity of acupuncture versus dry needling/trigger point acupuncture.

the vignettes used to create the ama cpt dry needling/trigger point acupuncture codes describe that the practitioner locates the trigger point, inserts, manipulates, then removes the needle. in contrast, acupuncture procedures require a review of symptoms, physical examination, diagnosis, point prescription, location of and insertion of points in multiple body regions, repeated and/or continuous manipulation of needles, additional and/or reinsertion of acupuncture needles. acupuncture licensure requirements include set didactic standards with at least 660 hours of supervised acupuncture procedure training, examination by an independent certification body [national certification commission for acupuncture and oriental medicine (nccaom)] in most states, and 60 hours of continuing education every four years in most states. medical acupuncturist requirements include 300 hours of systematic acupuncture training, certification through the american board of medical acupuncture, and 150 hours of continuing education every 10 years.

in contrast, to practice dry needling/trigger point acupuncture, there are no independent, agency-accredited training programs, no standardized curriculum, no means of assessing the competence of instructors in the field, and no independently administered competency examinations. there are no set requirements for
supervised acupuncture procedure training, which may range from 25 to 75 hours of unaccredited coursework, and no requirement for continuing education. a physical therapist could perform dry needling/trigger point acupuncture immediately after a weekend course. comparing acupuncture to dry needling/trigger point acupuncture is like comparing apples to kumquats.

improved patient outcomes with acupuncture are reflective of the additional skill and intensity of the acupuncture procedures. the strength of acupuncture is the ability to treat symptoms beyond pain and the ability to treat multiple symptoms simultaneously. there is a strong and growing body of evidence to support acupuncture as an effective treatment for several non-musculoskeletal conditions.(*see appendix a) for example, acupuncture is an effective adjunct treatment for the mental health conditions of anxiety, depression and insomnia.(*see appendix b) these mental health conditions can be both a cause and a result of musculoskeletal injuries and pain. acupuncture can simultaneously reduce musculoskeletal pain and symptoms of anxiety, depression, insomnia. this is just one example of the added value of acupuncture. so much of our population, particularly medicare beneficiaries, have multiple chronic conditions that can be addressed alongside musculoskeletal pain within the same acupuncture procedure. acupuncture has also demonstrated the ability to reduce the number of prescriptions for opioids, muscle relaxants, benzodiazepines, and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications which creates significant cost savings for insurers.(*see appendix c) acupuncture is able to achieve these enhanced outcomes when fully trained providers apply multiple acupuncture approaches simultaneously. one of the simplest subsets of acupuncture approaches is dry needling/trigger point acupuncture, which has only a limited application for musculoskeletal pain. only acupuncture by fully trained providers can accomplish improved outcomes in multiple symptoms simultaneously and add value to the system.

i respectfully recommend that the rvus for acupuncture codes are not reduced from their current values

i strongly oppose cms' proposal to reduce payment for physical therapy providers by 9% in 2021. if this payment reduction is adopted, access to vital outpatient physical therapist services will be at grave risk. some physical therapy providers will need to close their doors while others may choose not to continue to treat medicare beneficiaries and/or refuse to accept new medicare patients. this will make it more difficult for medicare beneficiaries to access the services they need, leading to delays in receiving care and, as a result, a slower road to recovery. this also will lead to negative health outcomes and greater overall cost to the system. the federal government, as well as patients and taxpayers, are better served in the long run by ensuring that the medicare program promotes efficient treatment of beneficiaries, which cannot happen unless there are enough providers to do so. as the u.s. population ages, access to these services is vital to our quality of life.

cms has failed to consider the economic and social impacts that this significant payment reduction will have on beneficiary access to physical therapy. this massive adjustment to the fee schedule will cause disruptive reductions to revenue that, in turn, will severely jeopardize patient access to care. these concerns are magnified by the significant economic hit physical therapy providers have taken in the past few months as a result of the covid-19 pandemic. by hindering the ability of medicare beneficiaries to receive care, cms is putting the health of medicare beneficiaries at risk while also causing detrimental harm to the integrity of the medicare program. i have serious concerns that the inability of medicare beneficiaries to receive care in a timely manner will have a compounding negative effect on their health and quality of life.

further, cms' actions are not singular, a fact of which the agency is well aware. other payers tie their fee schedules directly or indirectly to the medicare physician fee schedule. this one payment policy will cause access to be limited not only for medicare beneficiaries, but also veterans, tricare enrollees, and commercially insured and self-pay patients.

as stated above, i oppose the estimated 9% payment reduction to physical therapy providers beginning in 2021. i strongly recommend that cms halt implementation of any cuts to physical therapist services.

thank you for your consideration.

good afternoon,

i am a licensed acupuncturist in the state of maryland. after speaking with various colleagues in the healthcare profession, this potential change in regulation is very concerning to the integrative, conventional and unconventional medical communities for several reasons. to place acupuncture and dry needling within the same coding would be to misinform the public as to the functions of an acupuncturist and their professional practice. acupuncture is not the mere placement of needles but a thorough investigation, diagnostic evaluation and treatment plan. before the placement of needles is done, a comprehensive assessment is taken which includes a complete medical history, review of medications/labs and assessment of their physiological systems. we perform comprehensive physical examinations and gather information pertaining to their psychoemotional state. when necessary, acupuncturists refer out to mds, ers and acute and long-term treatment facilities. as one colleague appropriately pointed out, to place acupuncture in the same category as dry needling would be to say that a friend giving another friend a vitamin is the same as calling them a pharmacist. it is our responsibility as a community, government and medical system to accurately represent what each profession's skills and scopes of practice include. to equate these two within the field of coding would be a great disservice to the very patients and healthcare systems that we all desire to bring healing to.

on behalf of my practice and my patients, i appreciate the opportunity to provide comments to the centers for medicare & medicaid services in response to the 2021 physician fee schedule proposed rule.

as a practicing radiologist, i have significant concern about the impact of the finalized office and outpatient e/m policy on providers who do not frequently (if ever) perform e/m services. cms estimates that the 2021 policies will increase medicare spending by $10.2 billion, necessitating steep cuts by reducing the medicare conversion factor from $36.0896 to $32.2605, or a 10.6 percent decrease. absent additional action by cms and/or congressional intervention, the existing budget neutrality requirements within the mpfs will result in a reduction of reimbursement for radiology services by approximately 11 percent on january 1, 2021.

in addition to my concerns relating to the underlying e/m policy, i also believe that the add-on code gpc1x for complex e/m visits is unnecessary, and i do not support the implementation of this code. i strongly believe that the revised e/m codes are already designed to capture this level of complexity. the creation of this unnecessary code will needlessly redistribute additional monies within the mpfs at a time when physicians who do not bill e/m codes already face significant cuts resulting from the underlying e/m policy.

the covid-19 pandemic has resulted in unprecedented instability in the healthcare delivery system. physician practices, including mine, are continuing to adjust and reestablish a "new normal" for not only our practices, but the patients we serve. despite these efforts, the financial impact of the pandemic physician practices has been profound and the potential for an additional planned reimbursement cut (generated by the e/m policy) will undermine our recovery and jeopardize our ability to the patients in our community.

for example, and particularly in areas where covid-19 testing is not widely available, medical imaging is used to help confirm covid-19 findings, gauge the extent of illness and determine effective treatment. as radiology practices followed who and cdc guidance to postpone non-urgent care, and americans worried about infection risk, screening exams such as mammography are down 90% and delay in diagnosis of cancers will significantly impact the ability to detect and treat new cancers. in addition, seventy percent of radiology practices had to take out small business loans or apply for federal relief options to survive the pandemic's financial toll. drastic imaging cuts now may drive practices out of business, restrict access to care and cause a spike in adverse health outcomesincluding death.

now is not the time to implement any policy that will further exacerbate the financial instability already felt by physicians. i urge cms to reconsider its plans to implement the e/m policy on january 1, 2021.

my acupuncturist gathers my complete medical history and reviews my medications, labs and systems. they perform comprehensive physical examinations. they assess my overall wellbeing, not just my physical wellbeing. and the needling technique is drastically different from dry needling. acupuncture is comprehensive care that is very different from, and goes well beyond dry needling.

i appreciate the opportunity to provide comments to the centers for medicare & medicaid services in response to the 2021 physician fee schedule proposed rule.

first, i strongly oppose cms significant payment reductions for physical therapy services. if the 9% cut is implemented, physical therapy providers, many of whom are small business owners, will become insolvent and therefore unavailable to treat medicare beneficiaries, including medicare advantage enrollees. the result of this proposal will be massive unemployment; the shuttering of many small business (including in rural communities); delivery of unskilled care; significant declines in beneficiaries quality of life; and increased morbidity and mortality  all of which lead to greater costs and burdens on the already taxed health care system. the ripple effect that this decision will have across the provider community is monumental. cms must immediately halt implementation of the 9% reduction to physical therapy services.

second, i strongly recommend that cms include in the list of covered telehealth services the following cpt codes: 97161, 97162, 97163, 97164, 97165, 97166, 97167, 97168, 97110, 97112, 97116, 97535, 97750, 97755, 97760, 97761, and 97530 and 97763. the expansion of telehealth payment and practice policies to allow physical therapists in private practice and facility-based physical therapy providers during this public health emergency has demonstrated that many needs can be effectively met via the use of technology and that patients can have improved access to skilled care by leveraging these resources. adding these cpt codes to the list of covered telehealth services will better ensure a seamless transition when additional practitioners, such as physical therapists, become eligible to furnish and bill for telehealth services under medicare. moreover, adding these cpt codes, even on a temporary basis, will allow therapists who work incident to physicians to continue to furnish telehealth services when appropriate, therefore ensuring continued access and improving beneficiaries satisfaction after the phe ends.
third, i strongly support cms proposal to permanently allow physical therapists to furnish and bill e-visits, remote assessment of recorded video and/or images submitted by an established patient, and brief communication technology-based service, e.g., virtual check-in. however, i recommend that cms clarify in final rulemaking that facility-based therapy providers, who have been identified as eligible to furnish and bill these communication technology-based services during the phe, also are recognized as eligible to furnish and bill these codes on a permanent basis.
fourth, i respectfully disagree with cms interpretation that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 can only be furnished and billed by physicians or practitioners who are eligible to bill medicare for e/m services. physical therapists are recognized by the american medical association as qualified health care professionals and the cpt codes at issue are not restricted to use solely by physicians and others who may bill e/m services. physical therapists use remote monitoring technology in treatment to shorten healing times, reduce risk for adverse events, promote patient self-efficacy, improve comfort and quality of life, and increase the overall quality and options of care available. physical therapists use accelerometers and devices that collect physiologic functions both in real time (in person and remotely) and recorded. they commonly collect data that includes change in upper or lower extremity position, or displacement, that occurs over a given time period, heart rate, blood pressure, pulse, and respiration. this provides a greater understanding of performance of and response to physical activity as well as information to better gauge their home exercise program and determine the need for advancing or revising programs. physical therapists also use accelerometry to collect data that indicates when a patient may be experiencing balance and or postural changes that may be indications of increased falls risk.

physical therapists are recognized as qhps by ama; the definition of qhp supports the interpretation that physical therapists are qhps; and the remote physiologic monitoring codes are not e/m services. therefore, cms must revise its interpretation in final rulemaking to recognize that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 may be billed by qhps, such as physical therapists, who meet all statutory requirements, and that the billing of these codes is not limited solely to health care professionals who can bill medicare for e/m services.

finally, i strongly support cms proposal to allow physical therapist assistants to furnish maintenance therapy under part b.

as a health care professional who provides rehabilitation services to medicare beneficiaries, i am very concerned about proposals to be implemented under the 2021 physician fee schedule. on behalf of myself and the many medicare patients i hope to continue to serve, i respectively request reconsideration of the catastrophic payment reductions proposed for rehabilitation services. i also recommend that cms permanently allow telehealth services to be provided by rehabilitation professionals.

rehabilitation payment reductions

during most of 2020, i have done everything in my power to provide medically necessary care to medicare patients and prevent the spread of covid-19. along with my peers, i have met compliance to professional standards of care and medicare coverage policies while risking daily exposure to a deadly virus. not only have i spent a portion of every workday donning and doffing personal protective equipment, i have had to restructure treatment to accommodate patients kept in isolation and to utilize technology never before permitted by my profession in many medicare settings. despite my willingness to do all that is asked of me to assure patients are provided with the treatment they need, i am dismayed to learn that cms is proposing to devalue that care by an average of 9% per service. i am concerned that this severe reduction will result in reduced access to care at a time when patients are most in needespecially the patients i serve in nursing facilities. as a rehabilitation clinician, i am the face of health care every medicare beneficiary in need of rehabilitation therapy sees. i am entrusted with the care of medically fragile loved ones who must be carefully and competently treated. as a caring professional, i am very concerned that the impending payment reductions could result in medicare beneficiaries being severely challenged to access the rehab care they need. these reductions could also yield an economically devastating blow to all rehabilitation professions.

i love the work i do and i know the skills i have are needed for the medically complex population in our nation's nursing facilities. we are already facing cuts to rehab and we have additional cuts on the horizon. i am concerned that these additional reductions in payments will disallow and gradually dissolve a sufficient workforce to service those who need rehabilitation services. i respectfully request that you reconsider the reductions to rehabilitation therapy that cms is putting into place for 2021.

telehealth

with respect to telehealth services, it was gratifying to learn that cms expanded permission for rehabilitation therapists to use telehealth during the public health emergency. for patients unable to participate in traditional hands-on treatment, it was welcomed relief to have the opportunity to utilize telehealth in a way non-medicare treatment has been proven to be effective. as the pandemic continues and exposure risks remain, it would be best for both the patient and rehabilitation provider to have telehealth as a viable option when developing a plan of care. also and despite the duration of the public health emergency, i ask cms to allow me the professional discretion to use telehealth when it would be in the patient's best interest. out of the necessity to restructure treatment from traditional medicare models during the pandemic, we have learned telehealth is often a viable option with positive outcomes. outside the medicare community, we know that telehealth is a preferred method of treatment under certain circumstances. as a fully credentialed and professional health care provider, i ask cms to allow me to include telehealth among the acceptable treatment options.

thank you very much for the opportunity to submit these comments regarding the proposed physician fee schedule for 2021. hopefully, these comments provide evidence of my concerns and my desire to provide efficient and effective rehabilitation therapy.
12522:
i appreciate the opportunity to provide comments to the centers for medicare & medicaid services in response to the 2021 physician fee schedule proposed rule.

i work at fox rehabilitation, a large private practice of physical, occupational, and speech therapists who specialize in providing housecalls to medicare beneficiaries under part b. our typical patient is in their mid-80s with 5 comorbidities. in 2019, we provided over 1.5 million housecalls to medicare beneficiaries to improve their functional status and keep them healthy and safe at home. like cms independence at home initiative, this level of service from a pt, ot, or slp provides a unique opportunity to reduce costs to medicare while also improving overall health outcomes and functional independence.

i strongly oppose cms significant payment reductions for outpatient therapy services. a 9% cut to outpatient therapy will drastically impact my practices ability to care for patients. we will not be the only practice who will have to make tough decisions in response. we will have to consider pay cuts, increased productivity expectations, and reducing all the resources provided to clinicians to ensure the quality of their care. this will no doubt make it more difficult for beneficiaries to access the quality care they have become accustomed to receiving from our practice. patients who are unable to access care will have to turn to lesser trained professionals who cannot appropriately assess and dose exercise for them or go without care all together. lack of care will cause their quality of life to decline, leading to increased hospitalizations, and many moving to more intense levels of care that will fuel increased costs to the medicare system.

in addition, this cut will be compounded by the impact of the current public health emergency. as providers in the home, we have seen many patients who would not go to outpatient clinics due to fear of covid-19 but would allow us into their home to receive care. we have worked through the same difficulties with ppe that other front-line responders have had while serving this most vulnerable population. reducing payment for our services during this public health emergency is an irresponsible decision and puts medicare beneficiaries at risk of not being able to access care in the safest way possible.

separately, i would encourage cms to add cpt codes typically billed by physical, occupational, and speech therapists to the list of covered telehealth services. as a practice we have found telehealth to be a vital tool for appropriate patients during this public health emergency and have worked hard to ensure it is used responsibly. adding these services now will ensure an easy transition when physical, occupational, and speech therapists are included as telehealth providers in the future. i also strongly support cms proposal to permanently allow therapists to furnish and bill e-visits, remote assessment of recorded video and/or images submitted by an established patient, and brief communication technology-based service, e.g., virtual check-in.

i would also encourage cms to allow therapists the ability to utilize cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458. remote monitoring of patients would allow us a greater understanding of performance of and response to physical activity as well as information to better gauge a patients home exercise program and determine the need for advancing or revising programs. cms must revise its interpretation to recognize that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 may be billed by all qualified healthcare professionals who meet all statutory requirements, and that the billing of these codes is not limited solely to health care professionals who can bill medicare for e/m services.

finally, i strongly support cms proposal to allow assistants to furnish maintenance therapy under part b.

31121:
i appreciate the opportunity to share my feedback related to the proposed 2021 revisions to payment policies under the physician fee schedule and other revisions to medicare part b (cms-1734-p).

i am strongly opposed to cms' proposal to reduce payment for physical, occupational and speech language pathology therapy providers by 9% in cy 2021. if this payment reduction is adopted, access to vital therapy services will be at great risk. these drastic proposed payment reductions may cause therapy providers to reduce services, close their doors or choose to discontinue caring for medicare beneficiaries. this will make it more difficult for medicare beneficiaries to access the services they need to return to their prior level of function after an injury or illness or to maintain their quality of life. ultimately, this will lead to negative health outcomes and greater overall costs to the health system. the federal government, as well as patients and taxpayers, are better served by ensuring that the medicare program promotes efficient treatment of beneficiaries and just reimbursement to providers in providing this therapy access. as the u.s. population continues to age, access to these services is critical to our quality of life.

i urge you to consider the economic and social impacts that this significant proposed payment reduction will have on beneficiary especially given the current pandemic and its effect on beneficiaries and our economy. this massive adjustment to the fee schedule, in addition to the current payment reductions including sequestration, multiple procedure payment reduction (mppr) and the future reduction in payment for services by physical and occupational therapy assistant (beginning in 2022) would greatly challenge the financial viability of therapy providers. these proposed cuts are magnified by the significant economic impact physical, occupational and speech language pathology therapy providers have experienced in the past several months as a result of the covid-19 pandemic. the combination of these proposed reductions in reimbursement and effects of the pandemic will ultimately impact the welfare of medicare beneficiaries. i have serious concerns that the inability of medicare beneficiaries to have access to the skilled physical, occupational and speech therapy care they need and deserve will have a compounding negative effect on their health and wellbeing.

this reduction will not only impact medicare beneficiaries but other patients as well because many payers tie their fee schedules directly or indirectly to the medicare physician fee schedule. this one payment policy will cause access to be limited not only for medicare beneficiaries, but also veterans, tricare enrollees, and commercially insured and self-pay patients.

in summary, i strongly oppose the proposed medicare physician fee schedule changes which are estimated to be a 9% reduction in reimbursement for physical, occupational and speech language pathology therapy providers in cy 2021. i strongly urge cms to halt any cuts to the physician fee schedule and work with congress and stakeholders to find an alternative solution to offset the impact of increasing rvus of evaluation and management codes.

thank you for the opportunity to provide comments related to this proposed rule. should you have any questions concerning these comments, please contact me.
16031:
i am asking cms to add the adaptive behavior services codes (97151, 97152, 97153, 97154, 97155, 97156, 97157, 97158) to the proposed cms category 3 list, so telehealth services can remain as broadly available as possible for children with autism spectrum disorder (asd).

the responsiveness of cms in adding these codes temporarily to the medicare telehealth list during the public health emergency (phe) has ensured that individuals affected by autism spectrum disorder have had access to medically necessary treatment during the phe with minimal disruption. to keep our patients safe, we have developed comprehensive protocols to identify patients who can benefit from telehealth services, trained our behavior analysts and behavior technicians in telehealth protocols, and addressed the concerns of parents and caregivers by prioritizing safety issues, such as increased aggression toward others, self-injurious behavior, mask wearing challenges, and inadequate hygiene.

while some of our patients receive in-person services or a combination of in-person services and virtual care, many of our patients are medically fragile or have family members who are medically fragile and only receive services virtually. these patients are unlikely to resume in-person services immediately upon the termination of the phe, and their services could be disrupted to their great detriment if telehealth is ended abruptly.

during the phe, behavior analysts have collected data to identify the treatment domains in which telehealth is most effective, and we anticipate peer-reviewed journals to publish the fields findings in due course, providing the supporting documentation to illustrate the clinical benefit derived from telehealth services. as the proposed rule suggests, this process is not likely to align with the end of the phe. by adding the adaptive behavior codes to cms category 3, behavior analysts will have the opportunity to conduct the reviews and develop the evidence that cms requires to add the codes to the medicare telehealth services list on a permanent basis.

thank you for your consideration.

sincerely,
alice arabian, m.s., bcba

i am writing in response to the request for comments on the centers for medicare & medicaid services' recently proposed 2021 revisions to payment policies under the physician fee schedule and other revisions to medicare part b (cms-1734-p).

i strongly oppose cms' proposal to reduce payment for physical therapy providers by 9% in 2021. if this payment reduction is adopted, access to vital outpatient physical therapist services will be at grave risk. some physical therapy providers will need to close their doors while others may choose not to continue to treat medicare beneficiaries and/or refuse to accept new medicare patients. this will make it more difficult for medicare beneficiaries to access the services they need, leading to delays in receiving care and, as a result, a slower road to recovery. this also will lead to negative health outcomes and greater overall cost to the system. the federal government, as well as patients and taxpayers, are better served in the long run by ensuring that the medicare program promotes efficient treatment of beneficiaries, which cannot happen unless there are enough providers to do so. as the u.s. population ages, access to these services is vital to our quality of life.

cms has failed to consider the economic and social impacts that this significant payment reduction will have on beneficiary access to physical therapy. this massive adjustment to the fee schedule will cause disruptive reductions to revenue that, in turn, will severely jeopardize patient access to care. these concerns are magnified by the significant economic hit physical therapy providers have taken in the past few months as a result of the covid-19 pandemic. by hindering the ability of medicare beneficiaries to receive care, cms is putting the health of medicare beneficiaries at risk while also causing detrimental harm to the integrity of the medicare program. i have serious concerns that the inability of medicare beneficiaries to receive care in a timely manner will have a compounding negative effect on their health and quality of life.

further, cms' actions are not singular, a fact of which the agency is well aware. other payers tie their fee schedules directly or indirectly to the medicare physician fee schedule. this one payment policy will cause access to be limited not only for medicare beneficiaries, but also veterans, tricare enrollees, and commercially insured and self-pay patients.

as stated above, i oppose the estimated 9% payment reduction to physical therapy providers beginning in 2021. i strongly recommend that cms halt implementation of any cuts to physical therapist services.

thank you for your consideration.

12597:
i appreciate the opportunity to provide comments to the centers for medicare & medicaid services in response to the 2021 physician fee schedule proposed rule.

i work at fox rehabilitation, a large private practice of physical, occupational, and speech therapists who specialize in providing housecalls to medicare beneficiaries under part b. our typical patient is in their mid-80s with 5 comorbidities. in 2019, we provided over 1.5 million housecalls to medicare beneficiaries to improve their functional status and keep them healthy and safe at home. like cms independence at home initiative, this level of service from a pt, ot, or slp provides a unique opportunity to reduce costs to medicare while also improving overall health outcomes and functional independence.

i strongly oppose cms significant payment reductions for outpatient therapy services. a 9% cut to outpatient therapy will drastically impact my practices ability to care for patients. we will not be the only practice who will have to make tough decisions in response. we will have to consider pay cuts, increased productivity expectations, and reducing all the resources provided to clinicians to ensure the quality of their care. this will no doubt make it more difficult for beneficiaries to access the quality care they have become accustomed to receiving from our practice. patients who are unable to access care will have to turn to lesser trained professionals who cannot appropriately assess and dose exercise for them or go without care all together. lack of care will cause their quality of life to decline, leading to increased hospitalizations, and many moving to more intense levels of care that will fuel increased costs to the medicare system.

in addition, this cut will be compounded by the impact of the current public health emergency. as providers in the home, we have seen many patients who would not go to outpatient clinics due to fear of covid-19 but would allow us into their home to receive care. we have worked through the same difficulties with ppe that other front-line responders have had while serving this most vulnerable population. reducing payment for our services during this public health emergency is an irresponsible decision and puts medicare beneficiaries at risk of not being able to access care in the safest way possible.

separately, i would encourage cms to add cpt codes typically billed by physical, occupational, and speech therapists to the list of covered telehealth services. as a practice we have found telehealth to be a vital tool for appropriate patients during this public health emergency and have worked hard to ensure it is used responsibly. adding these services now will ensure an easy transition when physical, occupational, and speech therapists are included as telehealth providers in the future. i also strongly support cms proposal to permanently allow therapists to furnish and bill e-visits, remote assessment of recorded video and/or images submitted by an established patient, and brief communication technology-based service, e.g., virtual check-in.

i would also encourage cms to allow therapists the ability to utilize cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458. remote monitoring of patients would allow us a greater understanding of performance of and response to physical activity as well as information to better gauge a patients home exercise program and determine the need for advancing or revising programs. cms must revise its interpretation to recognize that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 may be billed by all qualified healthcare professionals who meet all statutory requirements, and that the billing of these codes is not limited solely to health care professionals who can bill medicare for e/m services.

finally, i strongly support cms proposal to allow assistants to furnish maintenance therapy under part b.
i appreciate the opportunity to provide comments to the centers for medicare & medicaid services in response to the 2021 physician fee schedule proposed rule.

first, i strongly oppose cms' significant payment reductions for physical therapy services. if the 9% cut is implemented, physical therapy providers, many of whom are small business owners, will become insolvent and therefore unavailable to treat medicare beneficiaries, including medicare advantage enrollees. the result of this proposal will be massive unemployment; the shuttering of many small business (including in rural communities); delivery of unskilled care; significant declines in beneficiaries' quality of life; and increased morbidity and mortality - all of which lead to greater costs and burdens on the already taxed health care system. the ripple effect that this decision will have across the provider community is monumental. cms must immediately halt implementation of the 9% reduction to physical therapy services.

second, i strongly recommend that cms include in the list of covered telehealth services the following cpt codes: 97161, 97162, 97163, 97164, 97165, 97166, 97167, 97168, 97110, 97112, 97116, 97535, 97750, 97755, 97760, 97761, and 97530 and 97763. the expansion of telehealth payment and practice policies to allow physical therapists in private practice and facility-based physical therapy providers during this public health emergency has demonstrated that many needs can be effectively met via the use of technology and that patients can have improved access to skilled care by leveraging these resources. adding these cpt codes to the list of covered telehealth services will better ensure a seamless transition when additional practitioners, such as physical therapists, become eligible to furnish and bill for telehealth services under medicare. moreover, adding these cpt codes, even on a temporary basis, will allow therapists who work "incident to" physicians to continue to furnish telehealth services when appropriate, therefore ensuring continued access and improving beneficiaries' satisfaction after the phe ends.
third, i strongly support cms' proposal to permanently allow physical therapists to furnish and bill e-visits, remote assessment of recorded video and/or images submitted by an established patient, and brief communication technology-based service, e.g., virtual check-in. however, i recommend that cms clarify in final rulemaking that facility-based therapy providers, who have been identified as eligible to furnish and bill these communication technology-based services during the phe, also are recognized as eligible to furnish and bill these codes on a permanent basis.
fourth, i respectfully disagree with cms' interpretation that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 can only be furnished and billed by physicians or practitioners who are eligible to bill medicare for e/m services. physical therapists are recognized by the american medical association as qualified health care professionals and the cpt codes at issue are not restricted to use solely by physicians and others who may bill e/m services. physical therapists use remote monitoring technology in treatment to shorten healing times, reduce risk for adverse events, promote patient self-efficacy, improve comfort and quality of life, and increase the overall quality and options of care available. physical therapists use accelerometers and devices that collect physiologic functions both in real time (in person and remotely) and recorded. they commonly collect data that includes change in upper or lower extremity position, or displacement, that occurs over a given time period, heart rate, blood pressure, pulse, and respiration. this provides a greater understanding of performance of and response to physical activity as well as information to better gauge their home exercise program and determine the need for advancing or revising programs. physical therapists also use accelerometry to collect data that indicates when a patient may be experiencing balance and or postural changes that may be indications of increased falls risk.

physical therapists are recognized as qhps by ama; the definition of qhp supports the interpretation that physical therapists are qhps; and the remote physiologic monitoring codes are not e/m services. therefore, cms must revise its interpretation in final rulemaking to recognize that cpt codes 99453, 99454, 99091, 99457, and 99458 may be billed by qhps, such as physical therapists, who meet all statutory requirements, and that the billing of these codes is not limited solely to health care professionals who can bill medicare for e/m services.

finally, i strongly support cms' proposal to allow physical therapist assistants to furnish maintenance therapy under part b.

thank you for your time.
i applaud the administrations goal of increasing access to healthcare for our nations seniors by reducing barriers for healthcare providers. unfortunately, the cy 2021 physician fee schedule proposed rule (cms-1734-p) contains multiple provisions that stand in contrast to this goal.

the proposed rule significantly reduces payment for services that could impact crna reimbursement by up to 11 percent. although i recognize that changes to budget neutrality requirements require congressional action, i ask that cms help lessen the impact of these cuts to crnas and the patients they serve. reducing payments to the providers who already provide the safest and most cost-effective care is the wrong decision for our nations seniors. it will also disproportionately affect patients in rural and under-served populations where crnas predominate. i hope you will help alleviate some of reduction to crna reimbursement so that patient access to care is not jeopardized.

while i appreciate that cms is removing barriers to ensure that clinicians can work at the top of their licensure, including allowing for a temporary waiver for crna anesthesia services, i was disappointed that cms did not remove unnecessary crna supervision requirements in this proposed rule.

furthermore, the proposed rule also allows all advanced practice registered nurses - except crnas - to supervise diagnostic tests as authorized under state law. like our aprn colleagues, crnas are wholly qualified to supervise these diagnostic tests, and should be able to do so as authorized under state law. the decision to exclude crnas is not based in facts or in evidence. this will disproportionately harm patient access to opioid-sparing pain management services at a time in which our country continues to face an opioid crisis and when critical covid-19 related and other diagnostic testing is needed. i strongly urge you to do the right thing for our patients and expand this provision to include crnas.

please dont hesitate to contact me with any questions. thank you for your work on behalf of the american people.
